questions.question: 1139. Which of the following disorders does not lead to hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation: Hashimoto thyroiditis is not associated with hyperthyroidism. It is associated with transient thyrotoxicosis, followed by chronic hypothyroidism. Thyrotoxicosis is a hypermetabolic state caused by elevated circulating levels of free T3 and T4. On the other hand, hyperfunctioning of the thyroid gland itself is referred to as hyperthyroidism. Disorders associated with thyrotoxicosis: Thyrotoxicosis. Clinical manifestation of thyrotoxicosis. Due to hyperthyroidism. Other causes. Primary hyperthyroidism (TSH, T4, +T3) • Graves' disease - Toxic multinodular goitre • Solitary toxic nodule. Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism. Secondary hyperthyroidism (+TSH, T4, +T3) - TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Thyroid hormone resistance. Release of preformed thyroid hormones. Subacute thyroiditis • Hashimoto's thyroiditis - Amiodarone-induced thyroiditis. Extrathyroidal sources • Struma ovarii (ovarian teratoma with ectopic thyroid tissue). Thyrotoxicosis factitia (exogenous thyroxine intake).

questions.question: What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas of the world?
questions.explanation: Autoimmune hypothyroidism is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficientareas of the world.The thyroid gland is typically enlarged. The circulating autoantibodies found in this disorder are:• Antimicrosomal antibodiesAntithyroid peroxidase antibodies• Antithyroglobulin antibodiesNote: Wolff-Chaikoff effect refers to iodine-induced hypothyroidism.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation: The most common thyroid cancer is papillary carcinoma.Major subtypes of thyroid carcinoma and their relative frequencies are as follows:• Papillary carcinoma - most common• Follicular carcinoma• Medullary carcinoma•• Anaplastic carcinoma - least commonThyroid carcinomas are derived from the thyroid follicular epithelium, except medullarycarcinoma which is derived from parafollicular C cells.

questions.question: A patient with a long-standing history of thyroglossal cyst develops a neck swelling. The biopsy of the lesion is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows psammoma bodies, which are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This type of carcinoma is associated with a history of long-standing unresected thyroglossal cyst. Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures often present within the cores of papillae in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. These structures are almost never found in follicular and medullary carcinomas. They arise from: 
      • Infarction and dystrophic calcification of papillae tips
      • Calcification of intra-lymphatic tumor thrombi.
   Psammoma bodies are seen in: 
      • Papillary carcinoma (thyroid, kidney, endometrium, lungs)
      • Prolactinoma
      • Meningioma
      • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary

questions.question: A pathologist is studying the following FNAC from a patient's thyroid nodule. Which is the most common site of metastasis for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The FNAC image is suggestive of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Among the given options, the most common site of metastasis is the lungs. Papillary Carcinoma of Thyroid Cells with Orphan Annie eye nuclei. The histological features of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid are: 
   • Papillary architecture 
   • Nuclear findings (enough to diagnose the condition even in the absence of papillary architecture) 
   • Nuclear overlapping, grooving, crowding 
   • Ground-glass appearance (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) 
   • Dusty and pale chromatin 
   • Intranuclear inclusion bodies 
   The most common mode of spread overall is through the lymphatic route, with lymph node metastases being common at initial presentation.

questions.question: In patients with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which of the following genes may beinvolved?
questions.explanation: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with gain-of-function mutations in the followinggenes:• NTRK1 (receptor tyrosine kinase)•RET (receptor tyrosine kinase)•• BRAF (serine/threonine kinase)

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common variant of papillary thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation:
The most common variant of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the follicular variant. It has the following features: 
   • Characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma 
   • Almost entirely follicular architecture 
   • Can be either 
   • Encapsulated - favorable prognosis (or) 
   • Poorly circumscribed and infiltrative - requires aggressive treatment 
   The variants of papillary carcinoma include: 
   Variant: Tall-cell variant, Diffuse sclerosing variant, Cribriform variant 
   Description: 
   50% of cells with height 2 times the width 
   Seen in older individuals 
   Have higher frequencies of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases 
   In younger individuals, including children 
   Diffuse fibrosis throughout the gland 
   Lymph node metastases are present in almost all cases. 
   Lacks BRAF mutations 
   Associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) 
   Beta-catenin mutation 
   1159 Variant: Columnar-cell variant, Solid variant 
   Description: 
   Elongated nuclei with pseudostratification of the nuclei 
   Poor prognosis 
   More common in children 
   Associated with Chernobyl nuclear accident 
   Note: According to the latest WHO classification of thyroid tumors, the non-invasive encapsulated follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma (FVPTC) has been renamed as non-invasive follicular thyroid neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features (NIFTP) to better reflect the indolent course of this tumor. This was done to prevent potential overtreatment and reduce the burden to patients of a cancer diagnosis.

questions.question: Which of the following patients is likely to have the best prognosis?

options.A: A 30-year-old man with papillary carcinoma thyroid
options.B: A 45-year-old woman with follicular carcinoma thyroid
options.C: A 78-year-old man with anaplastic carcinoma thyroid
options.D: A young man with MEN- II syndrome having medullary carcinoma thyroid

questions.explanation: Papillary thyroid cancers have the best prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate seen in more than95% of the patients.The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancers is dependent on several factors, including age (beingless favorable among patients older than 40 years), the presence of extrathyroidal extension, andpresence of distant metastases.The thyroid cancer with the worst prognosis is anaplastic carcinoma.
